comments.body:
Oh, one thing I was going to suggest - when this broke for me, I ctrl-clicked in VSCode to get to the type defition which brought me here.  It might be worthwhile putting a comment in here (or maybe above `interface Request`) giving a brief description of how to use this.  Something along the lines of:

```
/**
 * An Express Request.
 * @param {P} For most requests, this should be `ParamsDictionary`, but if you're
 * using this in a route handler for a route that uses a RegExp or a wildcard path
 * (e.g. "/user/*"), then `req.params` will be an array, in which case you should
 * use `Request<ParamsArray>` instead.
 *
 * @example
 *     app.get(/echo/(.*),
 *         (req: Request<ParamsDictionary>, res: Response) => res.send(req.params[1])
 *     );
 */
```

The example snippet has an invalid regex (guessing you intended `/echo\/(.*)/`?) and should use `ParamsArray`, not `ParamsDictionary`

If you add this documentation, I suggest adding another snippet for the more common case, to demonstrate that `ParamsDictionary` does not need to be specified explicitly.

Also as I understand it, the suggested usage puts the generic type on the method (saving the need to explicitly type the request and response):

```
app.get<ParamsArray>(/echo\/(.*)/, (req, res) => res.send(req.params[1]));
```

Good idea. That's now done, let me know what you think.

I put the comment on `Request`, although some users might look to `app.get` (and its other methods), so I'm not sure what the best place for this is.
What was the reason for this change?

Can we discuss this with #38888 ?

I must change it, or I won't pass the test!
I agree this is not the best solution, but it could fix all error perfectly.
Is it possible to create routes for non-standard HTTP methods? If so, then this constraint is too narrow.

@rbuckton Not through the helper methods attached to a router/application, as far as I‚Äôm aware (they‚Äôre defined [here](https://github.com/expressjs/express/blob/e1b45ebd050b6f06aa38cda5aaf0c21708b0c71e/lib/application.js#L472)).
